answers: Shǔ [accept Shǔ Hàn; prompt on Jì Hàn by asking “what other name is usually given to that state to distinguish it from the Hàn dynasty?”]
Three Kingdoms [or Sānguó Shídài; accept Romance of the Three Kingdoms or Sānguó Yǎnyì; accept Three Kingdoms of Korea or Samguk-sidae]
Qín [accept Qín dynasty or Qíncháo or Ch’in; accept Three Qíns or Sānqín; do not accept or prompt on “Qīng dynasty” or “Dà Qīng”]
parts: Give this name of an ivory-importing Bronze Age kingdom legendarily founded by Cáncóng, which followed the Bǎodūn (“bao-dwin”) culture near modern Chéngdū. Liú Bèi founded a later state of this name that was also based in Sìchuān.

Shǔ, Wèi, and Wú divided China during a period that shares this name with the Korean states of Goguryeo (“ko-goor-yuh”), Silla (“shilla”), and Baekje (“beck-jay”), and also titles a classic novel by Luó Guànzhōng.

This was the collective name of three kingdoms among Xiàng Yǔ’s (“sh’yahng yew’s”) “18 Kingdoms.” A brief dynasty with this name invaded Shǔ and Bā via the Stone Cattle Road and ended the well-field system as part of its Legalist reforms.

answers: order of a phase transition [do not accept or prompt on “order parameter”]
critical point [or critical temperature]
latent heat [accept more specific answers such as the specific latent heat of vaporization or latent heat of fusion; do not accept or prompt on “heat”]
parts: Name this property, which in one formulation is the lowest derivative for which a discontinuity in a thermodynamic variable occurs. The Ehrenfest classification sorts phenomena by this property.
The liquid-gas phase transition turns from first-order to second-order above this temperature. Above this temperature, the boundary between liquids and gases on a phase diagram stops.

This quantity approaches zero as a transition approaches second-order and as the sizes of discontinuities are reduced. This quantity is equal to the difference between the enthalpies of two phases across a transition.

answers: Swan Lake [or Lebedínoye ózero]
Marius Petipa [or Marius Ivanovich Petipa or Victor Marius Alphonse Petipa]
pas de chats (“PAH duh SHAH”)
parts: Name this Tchaikovsky ballet in which a ballerina performs an iconic series of 32 fouettés “(“fweh-tays”). In this ballet, the sorceress Odile curses Odette to turn into the title bird.
Most modern performances of Swan Lake are based on an 1895 restaging of it by Lev Ivanov and this choreographer, who also choreographed Don Quixote.
Petipa’s version of Swan Lake includes a “Dance of the Little Swans,” in which four dancers link arms while performing 16 of these sideways jumps consecutively.

answers: vampires [accept “The Vampyre”]
Lord Byron [or George Gordon]
Frankenstein [or Frankenstein; or, The Modern Prometheus]
parts: Name this type of character. In another novel, the orphan Aubrey travels around Europe with one of these characters named Lord Ruthven, who kills his wife on their wedding night.

John Polidori’s “The Vampyre” was inspired by this author’s “Fragment of a Novel” which he wrote during a literary horror contest with Mary and Percy Shelley. This Romantic poet wrote the Gothic closet drama Manfred.
That literary horror contest also led to Mary Shelley’s development of this novel, which is about a mad scientist who brings a monstrous creature to life.

answers: Tonga [or Kingdom of Tonga or Pule‘anga Fakatu‘i ‘o Tonga; accept Tu’i Tonga empire]
Fiji [or Republic of Fiji or Matanitu Tugalala o Viti or Fijī Gaṇarājya]
canoes [accept dugout canoes or outrigger canoes; accept pirogue or piragua or piraga; prompt on rowboats or ships; do not accept or prompt on “kayaks”]
parts: Name this modern-day country whose rulers took the title “Tu’i.” The British-born Shirley Baker became the first prime minister of this country under George Tupou I.

The Tongan prince Enele Ma’afu forcibly converted people to Christianity on the Lakeba island of this Melanesian country. Indian laborers were brought to this other Pacific island country by the British.

The Tu’i Tonga empire used kalia examples of these boats to cross vast swathes of the Pacific. Outrigger examples of these single-oar vessels, such as the Māori waka, were often used by Polynesian cultures.

answers: schizophrenia [or SZ; accept The Collected Schizophrenias: Essays]
Ten Days in a Mad-House
Susan Sontag
parts: Name this disorder whose name translates to “split mind,” a term that Wang calls “ableist and inaccurate.”
Wang compares her experience to this 1887 exposé of Blackwell’s Asylum. This book’s author, Nellie Bly, pretended to be mentally ill in order to investigate the asylum’s abusive conditions.

This author criticized the “romantic idea that the disease expresses the character” in her book Illness as Metaphor. Wang’s essay “L’Appel du Vide” discusses On Photography, a book by this author of “Notes on Camp.”

answers: Sergei Prokofiev’s Third Piano Concerto [or Sergei Prokofiev’s Piano Concerto No. 3; prompt on partial answers]
scherzo (“SCARE-tso”)
for the left hand only [prompt on “for one hand” by asking “which one?”]
parts: Name this C major piece that opens with an andante clarinet solo. It was paired with a similar piece by Maurice Ravel on a landmark 1974 recording featuring Claudio Abbado and Martha Argerich.

Prokofiev’s second piano concerto contains a second movement in this form that requires the soloist to play rapid 16th notes continuously throughout. This light-hearted form’s name comes from the Italian for “joke.”
Prokofiev’s fourth piano concerto was among a set of piano concertos commissioned by Paul Wittgenstein with this characteristic, the best-known of which was composed by Ravel.

answers: social networks [prompt on social media; prompt on networks]
dyads

city [or metropolis; accept Grossstadt or Metropole; accept metropolization or metropolitan area or metro area or macrometropolis; accept The Metropolis and Mental Life or Die Grossstädte und das Geistesleben; accept The City in History]
parts: Name these sociological structures that link individuals. The internet has allowed online services such as Myspace and Facebook to create virtual ones.

Social networks are made up of these smallest sociological relationships, which are classified by triviality and intimacy. Close friendships exemplify these connections that involve long-term one-to-one relationships.
Georg Simmel, who extended dyads to triads, analyzed modernization in an essay on these places “and Mental Life.” Lewis Mumford wrote a 1961 book on [This type of place] in History.

answers: Polish [or język polski] (The unnamed novel is Solaris.)
cyber [accept The Cyberiad or Cyberiada; accept cyberpunk]
bathtubs [accept Memoirs Found in a Bathtub or Pamiętnik znaleziony w wannie]
parts: Name this language. In another sci-fi novel in this language, the protagonist sees his dead lover on a spaceship also occupied by Sartorius and Gibarian.

Polish author Stanisław (“stah-nee-swaff”) Lem wrote a sci-fi collection partially titled for this adjective about the robots Trurl and Klapaucius. William Gibson’s novel Neuromancer pioneered a subgenre of sci-fi named for this adjective and the word “punk.”

A diary from the “Neogene Era” makes up Lem’s novel titled for “Memoirs found in” one of these objects. In Peter Weiss’s play Marat/Sade, prisoners put on a play that climaxes with Jean-Paul Marat’s murder in one of these objects, also depicted in a Jacques-Louis David (“dah-VEED”) painting.

answers: analytic propositions
translating [or word forms like translation]
a priori AND a posteriori [accept “from the earlier” AND “from the later” or close synonyms; accept answers in either order]
parts: Name this property. According to Immanuel Kant, propositions are of this type if they are true by definition, such as with the sentence “All bodies are extended.”
Quine argued that the “indeterminacy” of this process implied that analytic statements are only grounded in meanings. This process is the act of rendering the words of one language into another.

Two answers required. Kant contrasted the analytic–synthetic distinction with the distinction between these two qualities. Propositions have one of these two qualities depending on if their justification relies on experience or not.

answers: poset (“POH-set”) [or partially ordered set]
graphs
inclusion [accept answers indicating subsets; accept descriptions indicating that one set is contained within the other]
parts: Name these structures which contain maximal elements if they satisfy conditions given by Zorn’s lemma. These structures contain a binary relation that is antisymmetric and transitive but not necessarily connected.
Hasse diagrams visualize posets as directed acyclic examples of these structures that contain vertices connected by edges.

A common example of a poset is the power set equipped with this relation, which establishes the empty set as the minimum element. This relation’s symbol resembles a capital letter U opening to the right.

answers: Keith Haring [or Keith Allen Haring]
New York City [or NYC]
Venice Biennale [or Venice Biennial or Art Biennale; prompt on Venice or Venezia]
parts: Name this artist, who included a skeleton holding a zero-dollar bill in the predominantly-red 1986 mural Crack is Wack. Many of his works address the crisis surrounding AIDS, which he died of in 1990.
Haring worked mainly in this US city’s graffiti scene. He also took part in the 1983 Whitney Biennial in this city, which is also home to the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

At this exhibition’s 1984 iteration, Haring exhibited a painting that shows Mickey Mouse considering sex with the devil. The US pavilion at this exhibition is displayed at the Peggy Guggenheim Museum.

answers: potatoes [or Solanum tuberosum; prompt on Solanum or Solanaceae; accept potato blight; accept Irish Potato Famine or Highland Potato Famine; accept Potato War or Kartoffelkrieg; accept specific potato varieties but do not accept or prompt on “sweet potatoes” or “yams” or “ube”]
Chile [or Republic of Chile; or República de Chile; accept Araucanía; accept Captaincy General of Chile or Capitanía General de Chile] (The islands were the Governorate of Chiloé.)

Muscovy [accept Muscovy duck or Cairina moschata; accept Muscovy Company; accept Moscow or Grand Duchy of Moscow or Muscovite Russia; prompt on Russia or Rus’; prompt on Company of Merchant Adventurers to New Lands]
parts: Name this crop that may have reached Europe from the Andes, via Colombia. Antoine-Augustin Parmentier extolled this crop, which suffered Phytophthora blights that caused famines in the Scottish Highlands and Ireland.

European potatoes may also originate from an island governorate of this former Spanish colony. AmédéeFrançois Frézier introduced Europe to the giant strawberries grown by this country’s cattle-raiding Mapuche people.

Moche pots north of Chile depicted domestic ducks that Europeans named for this historical region. Richard Chancellor, Sebastian Cabot, and Hugh Willoughby formed an early joint-stock company named for this region.

answers: quantum numbers
spin [or intrinsic angular momentum or spin angular momentum; do not accept or prompt on partial answers]
zero (The number of angular nodes equals n − ℓ − 1 = 4 − 3 − 1 = 0.)
parts: Name this set of four quantities, three of which are symbolized n, l (“ell”), and m-sub-l (“M-sub-ell”).
For an electron, this fourth quantum number is either plus or minus one-half. Its existence was shown in the Stern–Gerlach experiment.
This is the number of radial nodes in a 4f atomic orbital. It may help you to know that the angular momentum quantum number of an f orbital is 3.

answers: Lenape people [or Lenni Lenape; or Delaware; accept Lenapehoking; accept Choptank or Esopus or Hackensack or Kechemeche or Munsee or Nanticoke or Navesink or Okehocking or Pamapon or Pompton or Raritan or Siwanoy or Tappan or Unalachtigo or Unami; prompt on Algonquian or Algonquin]
Fort Christina [or Fort Altena; or Hopokahacking; prompt on Wilmington]
log cabins [accept log houses or log buildings; prompt on partial answers; prompt on wooden houses or equivalents]
parts: Name this people whom the Penn family robbed in the “walking purchase.” Benjamin West painted William Penn’s earlier Shackamaxon peace treaty with Chief Tamanend of this native people of New Netherland.

In 1654, Lenape sachems settled the favorable Tinicum treaty with this fort’s last leader Johan Risingh. The Susquehannock who traded here waged the Peach Tree War after the Dutch besieged this capital of New Sweden.

Savo-Karelian “forest-destroyer” Finns who were exiled to Fort Christina brought saunas and these structures to America. In Charleston, Illinois, you can visit one of these dwellings modeled on Abraham Lincoln’s birthplace.

answers: dogs [accept itzcuintli; accept tz’i’; accept oc; prompt on Xolotl by asking “Xolotl had the head of what animal?”]
psychopomps
death by drowning [accept equivalents; accept shipwreck]
parts: Name these animals. A deity with the head of this animal wept so hard during the sacrifice for Tōnatiuh that his eyes fell out of their sockets.

The dog-headed god Xolotl served in this mythological role of guiding spirits to the afterlife. In this role, Xolotl would reunite dead dogs on the shore of Mictlan with their recently-deceased owners.

Colorful dogs on the shore of Mictlan would accompany souls to prevent them from experiencing this fate in the afterlife. The euphemism “visiting Davy Jones’s Locker” referred to people who died in this fashion.

answers: Brazil [or Brasil; or Federative Republic of Brazil or República Federativa do Brasil]
mediums [prompt on spirit channelers]
Emanuel Swedenborg [or Emanuel Swedberg]
parts: Name this country where Chico Xavier helped spread Spiritism, a religious belief about contacting the dead, by channeling a spirit called Emmanuel.
Kardec wrote an instructional book for Spiritist examples of these people, such as Chico Xavier. These people channel spirits using methods like séances (“SAY-on-sizz”) and Ouija boards.
Kardec titled one of his books on Spiritism Heaven and Hell, a title he likely borrowed from this Swedish theologian. This mystic also described his revelations in True Christian Religion.

answers: Nadine Gordimer
apartheid
Ludwig van Beethoven [accept Beethoven was One-Sixteenth Black]
parts: Name this author of the story “Six Feet of the Country.” A similar situation arises in a novel by this author which incorporates Zulu myth to describe how Jacobus finds the body of a Black man on Mehring’s farm.
Gordimer’s works, like the aforementioned novel The Conservationist, often oppose this policy, according to which White and Black people were segregated in her native South Africa.
A white apartheid activist tries to prove his own Black heritage in a Gordimer story titled for how “[this historical figure] was One-Sixteenth Black,” which titles a 2008 collection by her.

answers: paedomorphosis [or paedomorphism; prompt on heterochrony]
humans [or Homo sapiens; prompt on Homo]
Konrad Lorenz [or Konrad Zacharias Lorenz]
parts: Name this process that results from progenesis and neoteny. This process causes larval or juvenile characteristics to be retained into adulthood.
This species’s large head and flat face are oft-cited examples of paedomorphosis. This species split off from Homo neanderthalensis about half a million years ago.

This zoologist described how humans are drawn to cute child-like characteristics, which trigger our nurturing instinct. This biologist got a group of greylag geese to follow him by letting them imprint on him.

answers: punk rock [accept post-punk]
Patti Smith
Siouxsie (“SOO-see”) and the Banshees [prompt on Siouxsie Sioux]
parts: Name this late 1970s-era rock movement, which included the Sex Pistols. Other ‘60s covers by bands from this movement include a version of “Surfin’ Bird” by The Ramones.
The line “Jesus died for somebody’s sins but not mine” opens the transformative cover of the Them! song “Gloria” on Horses, an album by this singer of “Because the Night.”

The highest-charting UK hit for this British post-punk band was their 1983 cover of the Beatles song “Dear Prudence.” This band behind the album Juju also recorded the singles “Spellbound” and “Hong Kong Garden.”

answers: Rio Tinto Group
copper [or Cu; accept porphyry copper; accept Resolution Copper; accept the Copperbelt; prompt on metal]
Alaska [or AK; or Alax̂sxax̂; or Alaasikaq; or Alaskaq; or Anáaski; or Alas’kaaq]
parts: Identify this corporation named for an ore-rich river in Huelva, Spain. To expand an iron mine, this Anglo-Australian conglomerate destroyed the Juukan Gorge sacred to the Kurrama and Binigura peoples.

Rio Tinto and the BHP venture Resolution plan to mine this resource from sacred Apache land in Oak Flat, Arizona. A “belt” in Zambia and the DRC contains large deposits of this resource, which is Chile’s largest export.

Mining porphyry copper deposits from this state’s Pebble Mine will harm the Bristol Bay Native Corporation’s salmon fisheries. This state’s senator Lisa Murkowski supports oil drilling in its Arctic National Wildlife Refuge.
